title-group.article-title: Electromechanical impedance method of fiber-reinforced plastic adhesive joints in corrosive environment using a reusable piezoelectric device

abstract.p: Various nondestructive evaluation techniques exist for structural health monitoring of structures such as acoustic emission, ultrasonic impedance, and impact echo testing. However, these techniques often require expensive and sophisticated hardware with expert operators, limiting their applications to a certain aspect. On the other hand, a relatively new technique known as electromechanical impedance–based structural health monitoring has shown promising results as a local nondestructive evaluation method. To date, only a few numbers of studies have been conducted to develop a reusable lead zirconate titanate sensor for the electromechanical impedance method as majority of researchers have focused on damage detection performance. In this study, a reusable method for the electromechanical impedance method was proposed by using a lead zirconate titanate patch to eliminate the trial-and-error approach to minimize the time requirement for the electromechanical impedance method while reducing the cost for multiple measurements. The proposed reusable device was used to evaluate the damage of the adhesive layer between the fiber-reinforced plastic plates subjected to a corrosive solution while investigating the reliability performance of the device.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The use of fiber-reinforced plastic (FRP) composites in engineering field has continued to expand over the past few decades, and to date, its excellent properties have been well documented for their high strength-to-weight ratio with outstanding corrosion resistance (Akogbe et al., 2011; Bakis et al., 2002; Castro and Keller, 2010; Keller and Castro, 2005; Schollmayer and Keller, 2009; Yoshitake et al., 2011).With the growing interest of the composite materials as alternative construction materials to concrete and steel, nondestructive evaluation (NDE) method that can effectively detect damage of a structure is essential to prevent any catastrophic outcome. In addition, despite its excellent properties, certain properties are known to hold back its acceptance as a complete replacement for concrete and steel, such as joining of the composite materials (Bakis et al., 2002; Castro and Keller, 2010; Keller and Castro, 2005).

For joining of the composite materials, adhesive bonding is often used over the conventional mechanical fastening approach due to the low bearing strengths of polymer composite, better fatigue loading performance, and easier application ability (Haghani et al., 2009). However, one of the drawbacks of this type of joining method is the potential of debonding at the adhesive–substrate interface (Lim et al., 2010). NDE methods to detect damage or defects in the adhesive bonding layer have been studied for the past few decades. These methods include the time domain ultrasonic, vibrothermography, sonic vibration, thermography, ultrasonic impedance, and spectroscopy (Chen et al., 2007; Flynn and Todd, 2010; Guyott et al., 1986; Holland, 2011; Holmes et al., 2008; Shah and Ribakov, 2009). Although each has its pros and cons, the main concerns for the above-mentioned techniques are high instrumentation costs and can be time-consuming (Wang and Yuan, 2005; Yang et al., 2001).

On the other hand, a relatively new technique known as electromechanical impedance (EMI)–based structural health monitoring has shown promising results as a local NDE method. The EMI method uses the lead zirconate titanate (PZT) material that has advantages compared to other existing sensors, such as structural simplicity, low cost, and high reliability (Park et al., 2003; Song et al., 2004). To date, the EMI method has successfully continued to be reported by researchers for monitoring damage in civil engineering structures (Filho et al., 2011; Park et al., 2006; Pohl et al., 2001; Soh et al., 2000; Tawie et al., 2010; Tawie and Lee, 2010a, 2010b; Wang and Zhu, 2011; Yan et al., 2011). The principle of this method involves monitoring the changes in the mechanical impedance of a host structure with a utilization of a PZT sensor attached to the structure via the electrical impedance. The relationship between electrical impedance and mechanical impedance can be explained by the equation for the electrical admittance (Y(ω), the inverse of impedance) of a PZT transducer introduced by Liang et al. (1994)

where ω stands for the excitation frequency, a is the PZT geometric constant, ε33T is the zero stress dielectric constant, δ is the PZT dielectric loss tangent, zs(ω) and za(ω) are the mechanical impedance of the structure and the PZT, respectively, d3x is the zero stress PZT coupling constant in the arbitrary x direction, and Y¯xxE is the complex Young’s modulus of the PZT at zero electric field (Liang et al., 1994).

For the EMI method, the reusable approach techniques have been investigated by few authors on concrete specimens (Divsholi and Yang, 2009; Tawie and Lee, 2011; Yang et al., 2010). The main principle for their work is based on installing a bolt (with a PZT piece bonded) on a concrete specimen when casting. By unscrewing the nut, the part of the bolt with the PZT attached can be removed from the concrete specimen, allowing multiple measurements with a single PZT piece. In this study, a new reusable sensing technique, developed by the authors, and its performance were evaluated by utilizing a commercialized AD5933 evaluation board from Analog Device, Inc. using EMI method (Na et al., 2010, 2011). The proposed scheme differs from previous work by using a magnet to allow easy attach and removable process on composite and metallic components without installing any device onto the host structure. In addition, a series of experiments was conducted to assess the reliability of the reusable sensing technique to ensure its suitability, including damage detection on the adhesive joint of FRP composite plates subjected to a corrosive solution. The results clearly show an acceptable performance of the proposed reusable sensing technique for detecting adhesive layer damage. The aim of this study is to introduce the reusable PZT device and to evaluate the performance of the device with the commercialized AD5933 evaluation board to create a cost-effective, portable system for nondestructive testing of adhesives designed for real-field application possibilities.

sec.title: EMI measurement, data processing, and setup
sec.p: System setup to successfully measure the impedance of a test specimen is shown in Figure 1. The AD5933 evaluation board is connected to a laptop and a reusable PZT transducer, which is attached onto a test specimen. The combined system is portable, making it ideal for real-field application possibilities. The software from Analog Devices, Inc. (2009) is used to run the evaluation board to send signals to and receive signals from the PZT, allowing a direct measurement of the electrical impedance of the sensor. The built-in discrete Fourier transform algorithm returns a real and imaginary part of the impedance at each output frequency. The impedance measurements for each test specimen were measured from 0.04 to 10 kHz, 10 to 20 kHz, and 20 to 30 kHz and continued until 100 kHz was reached in 10-kHz intervals. About 5000 data points were retrieved by measuring the impedance from 0.04 to 100 kHz for a single test specimen. Multiple measurements were taken for each specimen at a room temperature of 24 ± 0.3°C to avoid experimental errors and to ensure reliability of the signature.

PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.p: The main indicator for detecting the effects of structural damage or change in materials characteristic is by observing the impedance signatures, which includes appearance of new peaks in the signature and shifting of the baseline in the lateral and vertical directions. To precisely measure the changes in the EMI signatures, a statistical technique known as root mean square deviation (RMSD) has been employed to give a quantitative value for the variation of PZT impedance signatures as shown in the below equation (Giurgiutiu, 2008)

where (zk)i is the reference signature of PZT impedance, and (zk)j is the corresponding impedance for each measurement time at the kth measurement point (Giurgiutiu, 2008). In general, if the difference between the baseline and the consecutive measurement is large, this will result in a high RMSD value. In this study, the RMSD values were calculated using the real part of the impedance as it is well known to be a better indicator for detecting any structural change when compared to the imaginary part of the impedance (Park et al., 2001).

sec.title: Reusable PZT setup
sec.p: The idea of a reusable PZT technique for the EMI method is still quite new as only a very few number of researches have been reported on this concept (Divsholi and Yang, 2009; Tawie and Lee, 2011; Yang et al., 2010). The signature received by the PZT is sensitive to moisture and can have an effect on the outcome. In addition, it must be attached strongly enough to the host structure and should be designed to be detached without damaging the PZT or the host structure. The reusable PZT proposed in this study consists of a commercial neodymium magnet that is made from an alloy of neodymium, iron, and boron to form the Nd2Fe14B tetragonal crystalline structure. As shown in Figure 2, a PZT patch is secured onto a neodymium magnet with a diameter of 25 mm where it was cut out from a single PSI-5A4E sheet into a size of 10 mm × 10 mm × 0.5 mm with key properties given in Table 1 (Piezo Systems, Inc., 2011). In addition, a copper material tape was used to extend the negative side of the PZT for cabling where the surface was covered with a layer of nonconductive commercial epoxy (Loctite Epoxy Quick Set™) to protect the PZT against moisture.

caption.p: Photograph of the proposed reusable PZT transducer.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.
Key properties of the chosen PZT (Piezo Systems, Inc.).

sec.p: Multiple reusable PZT transducers were made with varying magnet thicknesses of 3, 5, and 10 mm, and each device was checked with an Agilent handheld digital multimeter by measuring the capacitance of the devices for imperfections. Although the device seems ideal for metallic structures, it can be used on composite structures by simply attaching a thin metallic plate onto the surface of the host structure. In addition, it can also be used on thin parts of the composite structure by placing a support magnet on the opposite side of the reusable PZT transducer as shown in Figure 3.

caption.p: Attaching a reusable PZT transducer onto a composite plate.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.title: Specimen preparation and experimental overview
sec.p: In this study, 18 test specimens were created by lap joining two epoxy glass fiber composite plates (101 mm × 25.4 mm × 2.5 mm) with a commercial adhesive. The adhesive model is D-5251, manufactured by Daeheung Chemical Co., made of synthetic resin with a viscosity of 1300 cps at 20°C. Then, the specimens were left to dry in a room temperature for 7 days to ensure full curing of the adhesive. As shown in Figure 4, the overlapped length of the composite plate was 25.4 mm, and the thickness of the commercial adhesive was 2 mm, where each of the test specimens was cleaned according to the ASTM D 2093 before lap joining the two epoxy glass fiber composite plates together. In addition, three aluminum plates with a size of 180 mm × 50 mm × 0.5 mm were prepared for additional tests, which are mentioned later in this study.

caption.p: Diagram of a test specimen with dimensions.

sec.p: Table 2 shows the overview of the experiments presented for this study. Of the 18 test specimens, the first 7 test specimens were allocated for preliminary testing, which involved testing the specimens to set a threshold RMSD value for the experiments due to the fluctuation in the impedance signature of a specimen when it is measured at different times. Setting a threshold value allows a certain range of errors to be neglected during the test. This means that any RMSD value that is lower than the chosen threshold value will be assumed as an undamaged specimen. The second part of the experimental study was to evaluate the reliability performance of the presented reusable method by using a single test specimen, three aluminum plates, and several reusable PZT transducers. More details are explained later in this study. The last part of this study will include using 10 test specimens to evaluate the performance of the proposed reusable method subjected to a corrosive solution by conducting various experiments.

sec.title: EMI response of preliminary and control test specimens
sec.p: Variation in temperature and aging of the PZT material can influence the impedance measurement obtained from a host structure by altering the signature (Yang et al., 2008). So as previously mentioned, when using a PZT material for a chosen duration of time length, it is necessary to prepare a control specimen to set a threshold value for an allowable error limit as measurements from different times could lead to a small variation in the impedance signatures obtained. In this experiment, seven test specimens were used: one specimen was partially submerged in acetone for 3 days to verify whether the solution damaged the composite plate and three specimens were submerged in water for 3 days to compare with the remaining three control specimens. Figure 5 shows two of the test specimens, which includes a specimen with partially filled acetone (left) and a specimen with water solution (right) above the adhesive layer. The PZT patch was attached onto the test specimen and then it was covered with the epoxy, for protection purposes to minimize any error when measuring the impedance of specimens. Figure 6 shows the results of the RMSD value for all seven specimens where the highest RMSD value is less than 2% (1.84%). By comparing with the control specimens, the RMSD value for partially submerged specimen in acetone shows similarity, which indicates that the acetone solution does not damage the composite plate for 3 days. In addition, no weight loss was observed for the test specimen. This ensures that the acetone solution will damage the adhesive layer only when the specimen is submerged up to the adhesive layer for the testing. In addition, the RMSD values of the specimens that were submerged in water have similar results when compared to the control specimens, indicating that no damage has occurred. Since no control specimens have a RMSD value of over 2%, this value will be selected as a threshold value to decide whether a test specimen has been damaged. Any RMSD value less than 2% will be assumed to be undamaged in this study.

caption.p: Test specimens with solution partially filled and filled above the adhesive layer.
RMSD results of the preliminary test specimens.
RMSD: root mean square deviation; PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.p: To observe the change in the RMSD value for the above case, the impedance signature from one of the control specimens was selected and plotted as shown in Figure 7. A real part of the impedance from a frequency range of 90 to 100 kHz was retrieved. The result shows that there is a small change in the impedance signature before and after taking the measurement. This variation is mainly caused by a small change in the temperature where the effect has been documented by previous researchers, and such changes in the signature due to temperature changes can be minimized using a temperature compensation technique (Koo et al., 2007). However, to date, one must take into account that no complete solution has been proposed to eliminate the temperature effect as the signature does not always behave in a linear manner such as the one shown in this study.

caption.p: Before and after impedance signatures from a control specimen.

sec.title: Reliability of the reusable PZT transducer
Consistency performance of the device
sec.p: One of the factors that must be satisfied if a system is to be applied into real-field application is consistency. Due to the nature of the PZT material, when attaching a single PZT patch onto multiple identical specimens, the impedance signatures may differ for all specimens. One of the major contributors for this variation in the signature is condition of the bonding layer, which can be difficult to control in reality. In this part of the experiment, the impedance of the three reusable PZT transducers with a magnet thickness of 3 mm was measured, and a suitable frequency range was chosen by searching for visibility of peak(s) in the impedance signature, which can alter subjected to any structural changes. The measurement was between the frequency range of 30 and 40 kHz, and the result is shown in Figure 8. The overall impedance signature for all the measurements shows similarity with all three peaks located near the frequency of 36 kHz, and such small variation makes the proposed reusable method acceptable for sensing, using multiple reusable PZT transducers.

caption.p: Impedance signatures of the three reusable PZT transducers in the free state.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.p: With the consistency of the three reusable PZT transducers, their damage detection ability was evaluated. A single reusable PZT transducer was attached to each of the three aluminum plates (180 mm × 50 mm × 0.5 mm) available, and the impedance was measured before and after damaging the plate by removing 20 mm of the plate from the end, resulting in a total number of six measurements. Figure 9 shows the EMI signature of the reusable PZT transducers in the frequency range of 30–40 kHz for before and after the damage, where the real part of the impedance was retrieved. One important fact to note here is that although all three devices show consistency in the signature in the free state (Figure 8), attaching the device onto an aluminum plate shows a noticeable variation in the signature (Figure 9). In addition, the trial-and-error method to seek for a suitable frequency range is eliminated once the resonance frequency for the reusable device is known, which reduces consider amount of time when using the proposed device for the EMI method. Although 20 mm of the aluminum plates were equally removed from all the specimens, all of the changes in the signature seem to be different at first glance with quite a number of peaks being located in the frequency range of 34–37 kHz. However, when the RMSD values were calculated for all the specimens, they show a consistency value of approximately 6%–7% with the values of 6.64%, 6.99%, and 6.41% for the three devices, respectively.

caption.p: Before and after impedance signatures (real part) on the aluminum plates.

sec.p: To date, when applying the EMI method using the PZT materials, the PZT sensor is usually secured onto a host structure with a thin adhesive layer to measure the impedance of the structure. In the proposed study, the above results show a new finding. Although the PZT patch was not directly attached to the host structure by an adhesive, magnetic force that held the reusable PZT transducer was strong enough to obtain the impedance of the structure.

sec.title: Repeatability performance of the device
sec.p: For a device to be at an acceptable level, the repeatability of a system must be checked to ensure the reliability of the system. This experiment involved measuring the impedance of a test specimen by attaching the reusable PZT transducer with a magnet thickness of 5 mm and detaching it after the measurement. This process was repeated three times, and the result is shown in Figure 10. The small variation in the signature is due to the human error when reattaching the reusable PZT transducer onto the host specimen, so care must be taken when reusing the device for a precise measurement. The highest RMSD value for the three measured signatures for this case was below 1%, and this value may change depending on the accuracy of repositioning the reusable PZT transducer onto the chosen specimen. This result shows a possibility of quick sensing technique where a user can simply attach the reusable PZT transducer onto a desired area to measure the impedance and detach the device for future use. However, one must take into consideration that a small misplacement of the reusable PZT transducer when testing for repeatability can result in a large change in the impedance signature.

caption.p: Repetitive measurements from a single reusable PZT transducer.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.title: Surface PZT bond technique versus reusable technique with acetone solution
sec.p: To evaluate the performance of the reusable method compared to the conventional method of surface attaching the PZT patch onto a host structure, a reusable PZT transducer with a magnet thickness of 5 mm was used for this experiment. Three test specimens with surface PZT attachment method were compared with the three test specimens with the reusable method by measuring the impedance of each test specimen before and after submerging them in acetone. After 3 days, all six test specimens had lost 0.2 g on average, with debonding and deterioration being observed among specimens (Figure 11). The changes in the RMSD values are shown in Figures 12 and 13, which represent the results from the surface PZT attachment method and reusable method, respectively. As expected, although all six test specimens had same conditions when damaging the adhesive layer, the impedance of the test specimens with the reusable method had lower RMSD values when compared with the test specimens with PZT attached on the surface. This is because the PZT patch is further away from the test specimen due to the thickness of the magnet, resulting in a less-sensitive impedance measurement. Regardless, the reusable method has successfully managed to nondestructively damage detect the test specimens showing a RMSD value of higher than 10% at 90–100 kHz for two of the test specimens and higher than 5% at 50–60 kHz for all test specimens.

RMSD values on surface PZT–attached test specimens.
RMSD: root mean square deviation; PZT: lead zirconate titanate.
RMSD values on reusable PZT transducers–attached test specimens.
RMSD: root mean square deviation; PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.p: Previously, a threshold RMSD value of 2% has been set for this study through various experiments. A small vertical movement to the EMI signature was mainly the cause for the small change in the RMSD value (Figure 7). However, in this experiment, the RMSD value was higher than 2%, and the variation in the signature was substantially noticeable as shown in Figure 14, which shows the measurements of the test specimens before and after the acetone damage for all three test specimens. As shown in the previous experiment, although the consistency of the impedance signatures for the reusable PZT transducers was very much similar in the free state when compared with one another, the impedance signature varied when it was attached onto a test specimen. This is due to various factors including the position of the device, bonding condition of the adhesive, and the small variation in the dimension of the test specimens. Despite its differences, the RMSD values for this experiment were quite consistent varying from approximately 7% to 9% (9.36%, 6.87%, and 7.36%) between the frequency range of 50 and 60 kHz with signatures experiencing shifting and reduction in the peak size. The 2% variation here can be possibly reduced by attaching and moving the reusable PZT transducers until all the three test specimens result in an impedance signature that is close together.

caption.p: Impedance (real part) of the three test specimens with the reusable method.
RMSD: root mean square deviation.

sec.title: Sensitivity and damage detection ability with varied magnet thicknesses
sec.p: Various factors affect the performance of the reusable PZT transducer proposed in this study, such as the size of the PZT patch, bonding condition, adhesive type, and the magnet thickness. To test for the sensitivity performance of the reusable PZT transducer, three devices were used with different magnet thicknesses of 3, 5, and 10 mm. Each of the devices was attached to three separate test specimens, and their impedance was measured before and after submerging the specimens in acetone solution for 3 days, again losing approximately 0.2 g for each test specimen. The results (Figure 15) show that the 5-mm device was most sensitive to the damage in this experiment as it had the largest RMSD changes, over 9% for both the frequency ranges of 50–60 kHz and 90–100 kHz. The reusable PZT transducers with magnet thicknesses of 3 and 10 mm had all the RMSD values less than 5%, which suggests that the performance of both reusable PZT transducers were lower than that of with a magnet thickness of 5 mm. This suggests that depending on the host structure, the proposed reusable PZT transducer must be thin enough and have a magnetic force strong enough to be firmly attached onto the designated area for high performance, nondestructive damage testing.

caption.p: RMSD values of test specimens with varying magnet thicknesses in reusable PZT transducer.
RMSD: root mean square deviation; PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.title: Damage monitoring of the adhesive layer
sec.p: The results from the EMI method in this study clearly shows the possibility of the reusable PZT transducer to be used for an NDE including an adhesive layer subjected to corrosive solution. Furthermore, one could attach the reusable PZT transducer onto a structure to measure the impedance and detach the device after use for another measurement in the future to evaluate the structure for any damage. However, sometimes it is necessary to monitor the structure to detect the ongoing damage to predict and prevent any catastrophic outcome.

In this experiment, to evaluate the performance of the reusable PZT transducer for monitoring the adhesive layer subjected to a corrosive solution, acetone was evaluated. A test specimen with the reusable PZT transducer with a magnet thickness of 5 mm was submerged in an acetone solution, and the impedance of the test specimen was measured every 10 min for the first 420 min to observe the behavior of the impedance signature. As shown in Figure 16, largest changes in the impedance signatures were observed in the first few measurements as the signature shifted to the right with the reduction in peaks. With respect to time, the peaks of the EMI signature decreased and showed a horizontal movement toward the right. Since acetone is widely known to soften a wide range of adhesives, including the one used for this study, the gradual change (decrease in peaks) in the impedance signature can said to be influenced by the increase in the softening of the adhesive layer. This result of the magnitudes decreasing with time can said to be mainly influenced by the damping effect as a soft material has better damping effect than a hard material (Huang and Chwang, 1990).

caption.p: Monitoring of the test specimen subjected to acetone.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, an adaptation of the EMI technique by proposing a new reusable PZT transducer for nondestructive evaluation was investigated, including detecting the damage of an adhesive layer between the FRP composite plates. The damage was evaluated by monitoring the changes in the impedance of the specimen by exciting the reusable PZT transducer at the chosen frequency range using an AD5933 evaluation board. The advantage of using the reusable PZT transducer in conjunction with the evaluation board creates a system that is portable and easy to use. The following conclusions can be drawn from this study:

list-item.p: From the preliminary testing with the control specimens, there was a fluctuation of the impedance signatures when the test specimen was measured on different days, mainly due to the small variation in the room temperature. This shows that a threshold value is necessary when measuring the impedance of a designated area subjected to a small variation of temperature. In this study, RMSD of 2% was chosen as a threshold value.

Impedance signatures of multiple reusable PZT transducers show small variations, and their damage detection ability in terms of RMSD values shows consistency. This indicates that the reusable PZT transducers proposed in this study have possibilities for real-field applications.

The magnetic force produced by the reusable PZT transducer was enough to secure the device onto a host structure to measure its impedance. This is a new way of attaching a PZT material, as the traditional methods involve utilizing an adhesive to attach the PZT material onto the surface of the structure, which could be eliminated with the proposed method depending on the structure property.

When compared to the conventional surface PZT attachment method, sensitivity of the impedance signature subjected to damage was sacrificed at the cost of simplicity when measuring the impedance of the test specimen for damage. However, it has succeeded in detecting the damage of the adhesive layer in this study. This gives the possibilities of not only in civil engineering field but also in mechanical and aerospace engineering fields, such as automobiles and aircraft wings, where the component parts are relatively thin.
